title: NASA and SpaceX Ready for Crew-8
summary: NASA’s next crew to depart for the International Space Station, Crew-8, are nearly ready for launch, set to embark on a voyage of scientific discovery onboard the orbiting laboratory for the benefit of all on Earth. Made up of a diverse, multinational crew –  the astronauts and cosmonauts onboard Expedition 70/71 will oversee several key milestones in ISS development during their 6 month stay onboard the ISS, including key upgrades, certification flights of new crew and cargo spacecraft, and testing new technologies that will power the Artemis program back to the moon and beyond.

title: Astranis relocating hobbled debut satellite from Alaska to Asia
summary: Astranis is moving its debut satellite to a geostationary position over Asia after a malfunction last year derailed plans to beam broadband to Alaska, the Californian manufacturer said Feb. 27.

title: Northrop Grumman warns space sector employees of potential layoffs
summary: The company has filed a WARN notice that would impact workers at the company’s Space Park in California

title: Redwire opens new facility in Virginia to support national security programs
summary: The company is setting up shop in Chantilly, home to agencies like the National Reconnaissance Office, the Space Force's Commercial Space Office and the Space Development Agency

title: FAA closes investigation into second Starship test flight
summary: The FAA has closed its investigation into the second Starship/Super Heavy launch in November, bringing SpaceX a step closer to launching its third test flight as soon as mid-March.

title: Investors inject $92 million into French maritime surveillance constellation
summary: France-based Unseenlabs has raised 85 million euros ($92 million) behind plans to double its maritime surveillance constellation to 25 nanosatellites for tracking vessels in near real-time.

title: Odysseus Sends Back Lunar Images
summary: Intuitive Machines’ Odysseus lunar lander has sent back images days after tipping over while landing near the Moon’s South Pole. The U.S. company was not sure precisely where Odysseus set […]

title: FAA Closes Starship OFT-2 Mishap Investigation
summary: The FAA said today it has closed its mishap investigation of the second orbital flight test of SpaceX’s Starship, OFT-2, that took place last November. SpaceX must implement a set […]

title: SpaceX discloses cause of Starship anomalies as it clears an FAA hurdle
summary: "Several engines began shutting down before one engine failed energetically."

title: FAA closes Starship investigation as SpaceX seeks license for next launch
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday announced the close of its investigation alongside SpaceX into the second Starship flight, as Elon Musk’s company seeks a license to launch the towering rocket again.
